subject: RE: [junit] Testing object instantiated by Spring
msgSnippet: I think you could do either.  Using Spring for tests may require a different context for unit tests, perhaps.  But there s nothing wrong with manually setting
messageBody:
I think you could do either. Using Spring for tests may require a different
context for unit tests, perhaps. But there's nothing wrong with manually
setting up your class using the new operator. The risk is in the
duplication (in your tests, are you setting it up exactly as Spring will?).
I'd probably start with using new, and if things start to get complex, then
figure out how to use Spring (which isn't that hard I believe).

-Larry

-----Original Message-----
From: Yagiz Erkan [mailto:yagizerkan@...]
Sent: Friday, December 10, 2004 11:50 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Testing object instantiated by Spring


Hi all,

I'm testing a class that Spring creates an instance for me at runtime
(and my code is using it through the interface type) therefore I never
do "new MyClass()" in the production code. In the programmer tests,
would you use the same method of creating the concrete class or would
you call new MyClass() to keep it simple?

Thanks,
